is a small town about 15 miles southeast of
, also known as "Little India" as it's home to the second largest ethnic Indian population in the country, just behind

.

There's a similar (lack of) atmosphere to neighboring

, but it's a great place to pick up an embroidered sari, woof down a tasty malasa dosa, buy the latest pirated "Best of Kareena Kapoor" compilation and catch a recent Bollywood flick on the large screen.
The 605 Freeway runs through Artesia and connects to the 5, 91, and 105 freeways. South St is the Artesia exit.
The Little India stretch of Pioneer Blvd only runs for a couple blocks and is easily walkable. If you're varying off of Pioneer Blvd, you'll probably want a car, or catch an occasional bus.

value: hours=Box office opens at 3:30PM M-F, Sa-Su 12PM
content=An 8-screen cinema complex showing predominately Indian films with English subtitles, and the occasional film from other parts of the sub-continent and East Asia.
hours=Open to public M-Th 2PM-5PM, F 2PM-5:30PM, Sa 1PM-4:45PM and 7PM-midnight, Su - check website for hours
content=Ice skating rink best known for being co-owned by Olympic medal figure skater Michelle Kwan.
content=A pretty standard and well-stocked Indian grocery store.
content=They carry every imaginable Indian spice.
content=Well stocked with Bollywood dvds and videos, soundtracks and a small selection of Hindustani cd's.
content=Large selection of sweets and savories. They will customize a gift box of your choices.

While Indian food dominates, there are also several Chinese, Vietnamese, Italian and Bangladeshi restaurants scattered around off the main parts of Pioneer Blvd and South St.

value: content=A relatively small but tasty menu of snacks and South Indian specialties, including tasty dosas and uttapam.
content=A selection of good dosas and snacks, very popular.

content=It wouldn't quite qualify as "Little India" if there weren't two near-identically named restaurants on the same block. This one serves typical North Indian snacks and Punjabi staples including a mediocre but cheap thali. The icy mango lassi nearly makes up for the boring food, which is served on styrofoam plates.
content=One of the finest vegetarian restaurants in the area. Specialty is Rajashthani/Gujarati style lunch and dinners.
content=Great Northern Indian and Punjabi food.

content=Tucked away in a minimall, this is the place to pick up some halal meat, or have a quick bite to eat, Bangladeshi style. There's a small selection of authentic fish and vegetable curries and biryani.
